result.execSummary:
The defendant Michael John Boroczk Jr. was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Theft-Movable Property <=$2500 [Modifiers: as a Party to a Crime, Penalty-Theft if Value <=$2500, Penalties for Misdemeanors-Class "A"], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Also to pay extradition costs of $484.
May be served under the Huber Law as long as the defendant reports and remains alcohol and controlled substance free.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

chargeModifiers.descr: as a Party to a Crime

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

records.addlTxt: to cancel warrant
Notification - In custody - Green County Jail

Michael John Boroczk, defendant appeared in Court in person with counsel Joseph Pecora.
Jeffrey Duane Kohl appeared as prosecuting attorney. Modifier 939.61(1)(a) stricken pursuant to plea agreement. Defendant enters no contest plea. Sentence to 60 days in Green County jail with Huber, 60 days credit, payment of court costs and $484 extradition costs. Payment plan of $25/mo granted, payments to be due on the 23rd of each month.
Stipulation and Order Amending Conditions of Bond (strike requirement that defendant be in presence of Kristine Madsen or Michael Boroczk Sr.)

Defendant Michael John Boroczk Jr in court with Attorney Joseph Pecora. Defendant's mother Kristine Madsen in court by phone means. Gary Luhman appeared as prosecuting attorney. Mr Pecora is requesting for a change in bond conditions. Defendant's Mother is asking for the changes. State has no objection to the modifications. Court grants modifications to the bond.
